Author: Jiral#8557
Content: @jl777c may I ask an unrelated blockchain pow questions?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok

Author: Jiral#8557
Content: in eth PoW (this is a fork of eth) what is the meaning of nonce and does predeterming nonce lead to being able to solve blocks easier?

Author: Jiral#8557
Content: There are some people solving Waltonchain blocks with 0x999999xyz nonce while normally its completely random

Author: Jiral#8557
Content: https://i.imgur.com/1C4ydhc.jpg

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nonce is just a part of the blockheader you can change so the hash changes. probably there are other parts of the blockheader that are being changed to keep the nonce constant. you still need to mine by changing the block header, hashing it, checking it, etc.

Author: Jiral#8557
Content: I see so they are only able to do it after they find a block normally?

Author: Jiral#8557
Content: hmm weird that they're doing it if they're mining normally, thanks for your answer!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is how to find a block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: change the header, check the hash

Author: CryptoVegeta#7097
Content: Waltonchain blocks?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i am assuming it is like bitcoin, i was describing bitcoin mining. no idea about walton details

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@Jiral  Even now it is completely random. Its just that the randomness in the right most bits of the nonce are enough to find the block. I am presuming that the difficulty was low and they only needed to change the last few bits of the nonce to find a block. Finding a block means that  
* change the nonce
* Find the hash of the block
* see if the first `N` digits are zeroes (`N` is what the network calculates based on the total hash power available, its called the difficulty)
*If they are zeroes then you have found the block
*If not go to first step agian till you find it.

In this case, the difficulty might be low so that they are easily finding blocks so the nonces for many blocks have the same starting digits

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content:
" (N is what the network calculates based on the total hash power available, its called the difficulty)"
Technically, `N` is the result of the calculation of time of and between blocks and network "total" rate is inferred from there

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: ^ True, I just simplified it  slightly for this explanation üòÅ

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: I just have a thing when it comes to the guestimate of hash üòõ

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: @Mylo The result was 10,000tx/s and ~60,000 payments/s  from a few days ago, this is an expected result, but since then we have had major issues with it. Webworker has been given an SQL dump of the blockchains from last nights test, when he has some free time, he will analyse it like was done for the first large test with 1024 chains and we can then compare the result on Smk702's live stats site. There is either an issue with the cpulimit program I am using on the miner, or the sats calculations in the data aggregator for his website.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: ü§û its the cpulimiter... and it kind of points to that, as some chains appear to get `stuck`

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: If thats the case it will all be totally resolved by useing the built in docker cpu limiter, but you cant use that on normal containers, it requires swarm or kubernetes.......
